translated: Essential Collection of Dharmas, Scroll 8
Compiled by the Venerable Avalokitavrata
Tripiá¹­aka Master from the Western Regions, Chao-san Ta-fu
It is said that due to their inferior wisdom, they give rise to laziness,ğŸ”½Fond of practicing frivolous debates, and far from right knowledge.
Abandoning good friends, they enjoy associating with bad friends,
Destroying the causes and conditions of the Dharma, this is called wrong livelihood.
Not knowing the time and place, and those difficult situations,
What should not be said is said, the mind is always filled with worry and fear.
Not avoiding slander and criticism, always going out to beg for food,
Disdained by others, enjoying self-praising one's own virtues;
Giving rise to excessive greed, delusion, agitation, and wrong pride,
Deeply attached to the five desires, the mind does not rely on the right teachings.
Going against the king's orders, always harboring anger and resentment,
Losing one's right mindfulness due to madness, one dies at the wrong time.
Far from the Dharma teachers, one does not understand right and wrong,
And even when good people invite one, one gives rise to anger and slander.
Greedy for those drinks and food, always attached to sleep,
Such sinful beings will fall into hell.
If one is determined and diligent, one can give rise to pleasant rewards,
Therefore, relying on the true Dharma, one should take up good fruits.
If laziness is the basis, it gives rise to three kinds of faults,
Only diligence can eliminate all delusions and confusions;
That is, the three poisons are the causes, which can lead to three kinds of retribution,
These three are the roots, following into the three existences.
If one delights in laziness, then one abandons all good dharmas,
Many evils arise from this, and one will fall into hell.
Or grasping at that, one gives rise to craving, or abandoning this, one increases anger,
Thus, attached to these states, this is said to be delusion.
Laziness covers one's mind, like being poisoned and fainting,
In the deep pit of heedlessness, one falls into it without doubt.
If one delights in practicing diligence, leaving behind the defilements of laziness,
Liberated from all fears, this is then obtaining the portion of happiness,
If one intentionally is lazy, not cultivating the supreme pure Dharma,
Obtaining vast faults, this person is only in the portion of suffering.
Because of being bound by one's retinue, one will fall into danger and difficulty,
Therefore, in this life, do not crave for those sensual pleasures.
Moreover, the lazy one is always obscured by delusion,
Having not even a little bit of meritorious karma, one is despised by the multitude.
Moreover, the lazy one gives rise to sleepiness and dullness,
Destroying the door to liberation, the wise ones skillfully guard it.
Moreover, those who are lazy give rise to shamelessness and lack of conscience,
These two are the root of suffering, and later they experience great terror.
Moreover, those who are lazy neglect all their practices,
Such a person, though alive in the world, is as good as dead.
Moreover, those who are lazy give rise to agitation,
Causing the mind to be not tranquil, and at the end of life the mind is scattered.
Sinking in the mud of laziness, by what means can one transcend the ocean of suffering?
Only through courageous and diligent effort can one reach the other shore.
Moreover, those who are lazy are no different from animals,
They only think of food and drink, and have no other knowledge.
Because of greedily enjoying food and drink, they delight in engaging in impure acts,
Their desires are often lacking, and they always beg from others.
Even to one's own body, enduring cold, heat, hunger and thirst,
All due to laziness, one undergoes hardship and suffering.
Because of that laziness, all people despise and abandon them,
They deceive themselves, how can they end suffering?
Not learning the true vehicle, only greedy for delicious flavors,
After death, falling into evil paths, in vain giving rise to regret.
If one arouses diligence and abides in right mindfulness,
Permanently severing unwholesome dharmas, this is the wise one.
Such various sufferings all arise from laziness,
Knowing this is karmic retribution, one ultimately does not create it again.
The three poisons of sentient beings, moment by moment always burning,
The rain of the sweet dew of great compassion extinguishes them.
That is, the actions of body, speech, and mind, always in accord with goodness,
Revealing the three evil destinies, leading them to escape.
If one relies on compassion, one can head towards the bliss of tranquility,
Having pity on all sentient beings, like a mother loves her child.
For suffering sentient beings, one seeks to rescue and protect them,
Even ghosts receive blessings and are reborn in the heavens.
If one is endowed with compassion, cherishing all living beings,
This is called a great man, respected by humans and gods.
If a person has compassion, they can uphold pure precepts,
Like the moon illuminating the world, the light is always pure.
Causing all sentient beings to be free from sorrow, fear, and worry,
Therefore, one should always be close to compassion.
If a person is free from coarseness, adorned with compassion,
This is called a good field of blessings, with a reputation spreading everywhere.
Through the compassionate mind that universally nourishes, the faculties are free from defilement,
Abiding in pure right view, one is not far from enlightenment.
If a person is endowed with a compassionate mind, like the gods who are self-mastery,
For hundreds of thousands of lifetimes, they will forever be free from poverty and lack.
If a person's intention is straightforward, like gold that is to be valued,
And they further abide in a compassionate mind, this becomes an inexhaustible treasure.
If a person is endowed with diligence and always diligently seeks the true Dharma,
With the bright lamp of compassion, they explain to remove the darkness of doubt;
Always, throughout day and night, they do not abandon their compassionate intention,
Wherever they go, they happily explain without laziness.
The compassionate mind is extremely cool and refreshing, extinguishing sentient beings' afflictions,
Causing them to attain supreme bliss, and later obtaining the fruit of true permanence.
Therefore, the buddhas praise compassion as an inexhaustible treasure,
It is also like a pure pond, able to wash away all the defilements of wrongdoing,
It is the supreme adornment, destroying the darkness of afflictions,
Watering and nourishing the sprouts of bodhi, enabling one to attain the true and eternal fruit.
If a person has a compassionate mind, like a cow producing ghee,
Endowed with its delicious flavor, dispelling the heat and distress of body and mind.
The three realms of existence are like a great ocean, the three poisons are like a rushing current,
The compassionate mind is like a raft, which the benevolent one rides upon.
Compassion is the wealth of merit, adorned with pure and wholesome dharmas,
The virtuous always keep it in mind, this is called compassion.
Compassion abandons harshness, internally giving rise to all that is wholesome,
Eliminating the faults of afflictions, like refining gold from ore.
The compassionate mind is like a precious vessel, filled with wondrous things,
Increasing their wholesome roots, attaining peace and security according to their thoughts.
The mind of compassion is like a treasure trove, the use of which by sentient beings is inexhaustible.
It can break through their poverty and accomplish vast benefits.
The mind of compassion is always tranquil, delighting in cultivating various meditations,
Free from the realm of negligence, transcending the defilements of the five desires.
Moreover, one gives rise to a mind of kindness and compassion towards others,
Enabling them to attain lightness and comfort, and to be liberated from the bonds of suffering.
With a good and wholesome mind, one always stays far away from the defilements of wrongdoing,
Liberated from all fears, aspiring for the bliss of tranquility.
Always in accord with patience, oneself and others will be free from harm,
The world will all rejoice in seeing them, and they will later attain rebirth in the heavens.
If a person is able to abide in the unsurpassed treasure of kindness and patience,
All sentient beings will look up to them as if they were parents.
Compassion and kindness are unsurpassed, the root of happiness,
If a person lacks this mind, later there will only be suffering.
If the Brahma Heaven has a compassionate mind, and the Heaven of Free and Easy Gathering has patience,
The knowledge mothers of all vidyadharas are not as good as the practice of kindness;
Non-harming is the foremost merit, right view is the supreme goodness,
The tranquil mind is always at ease, and one attains freedom from all dangers and difficulties.
Therefore, one should always know to give rise to compassion in the mind,
And cultivate the immaculate wisdom of giving, morality, patience, and kindness.
Due to the purity of giving, one will receive twelve kinds of merits,
And be reborn among humans and gods, with wealth and riches unmatched.
If a person acts in the opposite way, they will receive faults in the same way,
Foolish and not enjoying giving, they will later fall into an evil state.
For the sake of wife, children, and relatives, they give rise to stinginess and greed,
Creating the causes for suffering of lack and insufficiency, always hoping and seeking without satisfaction.
If one widely practices giving, one will be liberated from the bonds of greed,
Destroy the banner of self-conceit, and destroy all ignorance and darkness.
Giving is the forerunner, leading to the production of superior states,
In the human world and among the gods, one will attract great wealth.
Giving is like a bathing pool, precepts can purify all defilements,
Using wisdom to observe well, one can transcend the three realms of existence.
Namely, giving, precepts, and wisdom, these three are like the light of lamps,
If a person skillfully cultivates them, they will forever be free from all the darkness of ignorance.
Desire and anger are like the great ocean, doubt is like the waves,
If one wishes to cross that perilous difficulty, one should cultivate giving, precepts, and wisdom.
Sentient beings are often insane, following whatever arises in their greed and attachment,
If one wishes to protect that mind, one should cultivate giving, precepts, and wisdom;
These three kinds of practices, I say, are like good medicine,
Well able to eliminate the afflictions and illnesses, all causing them to attain coolness and comfort.
The mind gives rise to wrong thoughts, producing the fault of negligence,
For those associated with lust, anger, and delusion, they are bound by them;
These three poisons are to be feared, like fire burning the world,
Using giving and other antidotes, one should cut them off and bring them to an end.
If one does not cultivate the practices of giving and so forth, one will be foolish,
This person will always suffer, seeking happiness will be impossible.
Wherever there are sentient beings, they create various offenses,
According to those causes and conditions, they receive various karmic retributions.
All conditioned phenomena arise from causes and conditions,
I have never seen evil causes without receiving painful retributions.
The mind does not delight in giving, the face always shows an angry expression,
This is the cause of poverty and destitution, therefore one should stay far away from it.
If one gives with a joyful mind, free from the stains of stinginess,
Later one will be reborn in the heavens, playing together with the gods.
Stinginess is like an enemy, its destruction is extremely terrifying,
It can cause all beings to experience the hunger and thirst of hungry ghosts.
If one delights in practicing giving, the life one is born into will be happy,
Therefore, the wise always praise giving.
Giving is like that light, wherever it goes, it is present,
If one is reborn among humans or gods, one will obtain offerings and respect.
Therefore, what the Buddhas teach is to skillfully cultivate giving,
Abiding in the indestructible, the supreme and firm place.
Those who practice giving well will subdue the enemy of stinginess,
Always using wisdom to contemplate, not allowing it to take advantage.
Giving is like that good field, and there are three kinds,
The seeds of the mind well perfumed, each obtains its own fruit and benefit.
First delighting in practicing giving, later exclusively upholding pure precepts,
Using wisdom to sever the defilements of craving, this principle is unsurpassed.
The world is all impermanent, and moreover has many faults,
If one cannot sever that craving, by what means can one be born in a superior place?
One should give rise to a great mind, delighting in extensively practicing giving,
If one abandons this and does not cultivate it, later one will receive the retribution of hungry ghosts.
Because of relying on giving, one further firmly upholds pure precepts,
This person in their later bodies will receive the position of a wheel-turning king.
Because of being endowed with those precepts, well knowing the proper and improper times,
Liberated from the bounds of suffering, they approach the path to enlightenment.
The gods do not practice giving, their blessings then decrease accordingly,
The wise ones, having understood this, should delight in practicing joyful giving;
Up to this life, I have experienced human happiness,
All due to his giving, I always recollect and practice.
Even if reborn among animals, I still experience happiness,
All due to his giving, this is what the Tathagata says.
If a person does not enjoy giving, he will later fall into the realm of hungry ghosts,
Because of stinginess, he always eats impurities.
If one enjoys practicing giving, one will obtain a cool and refreshing result,
If one does not cultivate such practices, one will be burned by hunger and thirst.
Because of previous heedlessness, one does not cultivate the causes of giving and so forth,
At the end of that life, one's own mind gives rise to distress.
With a joyful mind, one practices giving, and obtains the respect of the multitude,
Always obtaining auspiciousness, the obtained fruit is similar to the cause.
If a person does not enjoy giving, he himself does not enjoy using,ğŸ”½...
Always stingy with their wealth, in the end it will be scattered and destroyed by others.
If a person possesses precious wealth and offers it to revered elders and teachers,
This accords with the correct practice and is not a vain expenditure.
To the poor, the sick, and the weary, to all sentient beings,
Always delight in pure giving, and be their eyes.
By practicing such giving, having given, one attains rebirth in the heavens,
If the gods give rise to stinginess, they will soon fall and regress.
Cultivating the cause of giving in the human realm, one experiences the blissful rewards in the heavens,
It is not without cultivating the cause that one falsely attracts its result.
If one abandons giving and moral conduct, and also does not cultivate meditative concentration,
Such a foolish person, though alive, is no different from the dead.
If one does not delight in the true Dharma, then one's wisdom-life will be diminished,
The foolish do not cultivate and practice, though alive, they are as if dead.
If a person lacks the lamp of wisdom, their mind will be unclear,
They will be like an animal, covered in human skin.
Not giving, and being greedy, with faculties always scattered and distracted,
One should know that they are not human, like hungry ghosts fighting and quarreling.
Dwelling in loving-kindness and observation, cultivating giving, precepts, and meditation,
This is a peaceful person, respected by all gods;
Endowed with virtue, respected by the multitude, lacking virtue, despised by all,
Knowing this well, they are a human among gods.
Those who skillfully cultivate giving will attain wealth, happiness, and longevity,
In this world and the next, always delighting in giving with joy.
Beings, according to their own karma, are born in the five destinies,
Only the good causes of giving, seeing them like parents.
Understanding the causes of giving, and the excellent rewards they bring,
One should uphold pure precepts and be liberated from the suffering of the three realms of existence.
Precepts are the most excellent wealth, like the sun shining everywhere.
When a person's life ends, only precepts are their companion.
Upholding precepts leads to rebirth in the heavens or attaining various meditative absorptions.
In this world and the next, the radiance is unequaled.
If a person delights in rebirth in the heavens, even a small cause can lead to attainment.
Therefore, one should distance oneself from all evil and always uphold pure precepts.
If one can protect those precepts and joyfully practice giving,
later one will be reborn in the heavens and attain wondrous bliss beyond compare.
Wife, children, precious wealth, relatives, friends, and associates,
for one who upholds pure precepts, seeing these is not happiness.
If one gives rise to love and respect for the precepts, cherishing them as one would a newborn child,
then one will be free from transgressions and always be reborn in excellent places.
By cultivating those pure practices, giving and morality are all perfected,
Adorned with pure karma, one is reborn in the heavens.
Morality is like a treasure trove, able to give rise to wealth and abundance,
Fame and rebirth in the heavens come without seeking;
These three kinds of supreme rewards, even ghosts are able to seek,
How much more so a person with wisdom, who upholds morality with a pure mind?
If a person is able to protect and uphold pure morality throughout their life,
They will reach the place of non-extinction, forever ending all suffering.
In the past, through the three poisons, one was bound in saá¹ƒsÄra,
Morality is like pure light, able to destroy that darkness.
Morality is like a heavenly pond, adorned with all kinds of treasures,
It is also called firm wealth, which cannot be destroyed by water or fire.
Therefore, those who are upright have never violated morality,
Always give rise to a mind of love and respect, and attain the supreme tranquility.
With a determined and firm mind, do not violate the precepts,
Only the power of the precepts, always protect until the end of life.
If one associates with those who uphold the precepts, like being illuminated by sunlight,
If one gets close to those who violate the precepts, one's delusion will increase.
Free from the defilements of unwholesomeness, without the torment of craving,
Such a person who upholds the precepts is praised by the Buddhas.
Upholding the precepts is endowed with blessings and wisdom, good in the beginning, middle, and end,
Only the foolish break the precepts, no different from animals.
If a person upholds pure precepts, they obtain the covering of the robe of precepts,
If one violates the precepts, they are like one who is naked.
Because of upholding the precepts, one is born in the heavens, and the celestial hosts vie to welcome and serve,
In those gardens and groves, they play and enjoy themselves together.
Fully endowed with all meritorious deeds, firmly cultivating pure conduct,
This person is born among the gods, without doubt or hesitation.
Because of upholding that precept, increasing all good benefits,
In the supreme five desires, the mind does not give rise to attachment.
In this world and the next, the precepts are one's companion,
In that dangerous and evil path, they become one's reliance and support.
In hunger, thirst, and fear, they become the foremost protector,
One should observe well and abandon this, to what else can one turn?
It is better to use a sharp sword to cut off one's own head,
Than to give rise to violation of the precepts' ability.
This merit of upholding the precepts, cause and effect are both pure,
Attracting worldly and transcendent bliss, praised by all Buddhas.
If a person does not protect the precepts, there is no goodness in the beginning, middle, or end,
They will miss out on vast benefits and the highest peace.
Upholding precepts is the foremost goodness, which even generosity cannot match.
That wealth has a limited quantity, but the power of precepts is inexhaustible.
Because of the adornment of virtuous precepts, one is loved and respected by the multitude.
Know that all TathÄgatas become sages because of the precepts.
Upholding precepts is the coolest, removing the heat and distress of body and mind.
Therefore, always practice them and you will be reborn in the heavens.
Precepts are the ladder to heaven and also called the ocean of bliss.
If a person abandons them, later they will only give rise to worry and regret.
Precepts are like cool water, deep, vast, and always overflowing.
For those who uphold precepts, it purifies the defilements of body and mind.
Experiencing the wonderful bliss of the heavens and the supreme adornments,
All come from the power of precepts, caused by wholesome conditions.
If one abides in pure precepts, all good deeds rely on it,
Increasing moment by moment, without fear of evil paths.
If one exclusively cultivates pure conduct, using precepts to adorn the body,
This person, in the present life, will obtain offerings and respect.
Because of upholding the precepts, always avoiding all that is unwholesome,
In all those places, one will obtain happiness and peace.
If one upholds each and every precept, each having its own function,
Always being born in an excellent place, freely as one wishes.
Generosity, precepts, and wisdom, these three kinds, can give rise to a compassionate mind,
Always loving and caring for sentient beings, obtaining intimacy and service.
Precepts are like wonderful treasures, always valued by good people,
Forever free from all faults, one can be reborn in the heavens.
Endowed with pure wisdom, like gold melted free from impurities,
Always delighting in upholding pure precepts, one can be reborn in the heavens.
Causing all sentient beings to be at ease in all places,
Not committing any evil deeds, one can be reborn in the heavens.
If a person protects those precepts, using wisdom to discern well,
In their day and night, they are always diligent and never retreat.
Precepts are like that good horse, ridden and controlled by the virtuous,
Using true contemplation, not attached to the rewards of pleasure.
The supreme and wonderful bliss in the heavens, the gods playing together,
All come from upholding the precepts, and one can be reborn there.
The wonderful flower garlands in the heavens, the heavenly garments used for adornment,
The gods playing together, all are obtained through good causes.
There is a wonderful lotus pond, producing cool and fragrant breezes,
The gods playing together, all are obtained through good causes.
The various treasures adorn the palaces in the heavens,
The gods play together, all due to upholding the precepts.
In the heavens, the wonderful gardens and forests, all the flowers fully open,
Roaming and resting in the jeweled mountains, all due to upholding the precepts.
By possessing those pure precepts, one is born in the Heaven of the Thirty-three,
Just as a person entering his own house, immediately has no worries or troubles.
If a person protects those precepts, he attains the supreme life span,
When a person of broken precepts dies, he undergoes immeasurable extreme suffering.
Having understood the merits of upholding the precepts, one always delights in them,
One who skillfully protects the precepts will not give rise to transgressions.
By being able to protect those precepts, one skillfully abides in patience,
By means of the causes and conditions of tranquility, the multitude of people all enjoy seeing.
If one relies on pure precepts, it is like riding a boat or raft,
Able to transport oneself and others, one can cross the ocean of the three realms.
By the clear and cool water of precepts, one can cleanse the mind and wisdom,
And the flowers of the JambÅ«nada gold are offered by the devas.
If a person's mind is tranquil and always adorned with precepts,
One will be born in the heavens with self-mastery and experience boundless bliss.
By extensively cultivating superior practices, one receives the most supreme and wonderful bliss,
And plays in the heavens, all due to upholding the precepts.
If one upholds those pure precepts, it is like ascending a staircase,
With the power of wisdom always supporting, one is born in a superior and exalted place.
If a person has a pure mind and the precepts are without deficiency,
Due to the purity of the Dharma of precepts, one is always born in a place of peace and security.
Those who skillfully protect the precepts always contemplate and observe,
Free from even the slightest transgression, one attains the place of quiescence.
Precepts can give rise to that happiness, abandoning all faults and defilements,
Therefore, always protect them, ultimately eliminating sorrow and fear.
Because of upholding those precepts, at the end of life there is no fear,
In the three evil destinies, they are the foremost protection.
If a person does not protect the precepts, it is like being blind or having blurred vision,
If one is impure in the precepts, one will always be born in an inferior place.
Seeking human and heavenly happiness, precepts are the basis for that,
If one is impure in the precepts, later one will give rise to regret and distress.
A foolish person without precepts cannot be born in the heavens,
Therefore, the wise always uphold the precepts.
The wonderful five desires in the heavens, the foremost supreme happiness,
Are obtained through the purity of the precepts, and one attains many fruits.
The golden light of Mount Sumeru, the light of the precepts surpasses that,
Divided into sixteen parts, it is still not equal to one of them.
The light of precepts always shines brightly, surpassing the adornment of true gold,
All due to one's own good karma, one is born in the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
Upholding precepts has three grades, namely superior, middling, and inferior,
All according to the causes one has created, one receives retribution in the same way.
Because of upholding those precepts, one does not give rise to negligence,
Abiding peacefully in the true Dharma, one always attains all kinds of wonderful bliss.
Precepts can remove all defilements and always give rise to pure light,
Even if there were a hundred thousand suns, they could not compare to this.
If one upholds precepts at the superior level, one attains seven kinds of merits,
Which can be enjoyed according to one's wishes, as taught by the Well-Gone One.
By relying on pure precepts, right views always manifest,
Being reborn from the human realm to the heavens, this is not difficult to attain.
The precepts are a cool touch, never leaving the body,
Yet fools do not draw near, always experiencing various torments.
If a person with a pure mind well protects the precepts,
Endowed with those seven kinds of wealth, no one can destroy them.
If a person with a pure mind cultivates pure conduct,
Like a bird with two wings, flying in the sky without falling.
Because of upholding the precepts, one attains the pure fruits,
The most excellent among the excellent, then there is nothing higher.
If the mind is well cultivated, relying on the treasures of giving and precepts,
One will be born in the heavens and among humans, in the most excellent places.
If the body does not uphold pure precepts, and the mind does not delight in the true Dharma,
Without any inner or outer accumulation, how can one avoid the evil paths?
If one delights in the tranquil Dharma, one will be respected by others,
The inner and outer firmness is like vajra, no different.
The fragrance of sandalwood, agarwood, and jasmine flowers,
Are cherished by humans and gods, but do not equal the fragrance of precepts.
If a person cultivates giving and precepts, only wishing for rebirth in the heavens,
This becomes a cause of defilement, like poison mixed with delicious food.
Therefore, in those precepts, firmly uphold them and seek liberation,
Far away from those who break the precepts, like poison and like a knife and staff.
Thus, well-protected in the precepts, one goes to the realms of humans and gods,
Without precepts, one is despised by the assembly, and happiness cannot be obtained.
Knowing these merits, one focuses the mind without temporary abandonment,
It becomes the foremost protection, nothing is similar to the precepts.
Well-abiding in patience, it becomes the foremost adornment,
This becomes the most excellent wealth, not equaled by worldly treasures.
If a person cultivates patience, they will be respected by the world.
Therefore, always be single-minded and firmly cultivate it.
If a person cultivates patience, they will be free from the fault of anger.
In this world and the next, the virtuous are always praised.
The wealth of patience, the wealth of precepts, and the wealth of wisdom,
Such merits surpass those of the world.
Therefore, the wise delight in practicing patience,
And never give rise to aversion towards sentient beings.
Patience is like a wonderful medicine that can cure the poison of anger.
Due to the power of patience, it will not arise again and again.
Foolish people lack the wisdom of illumination, like the blind who see nothing.
Using the light of patience, lead them to the right path.
Due to the lack of the wealth of the true Dharma, one revolves in the five destinies,
I say that those who cultivate patience well are prosperous.
Anger is a deep fault, like a treacherous and evil wilderness.
If a person possesses the practice of patience, they will skillfully transcend it.
If one does not cultivate the practice of patience, they will lose their way.
If one wishes to leave the suffering of the evil destinies, how can they avoid it without patience?
If a person practices patience, they will attain peace and security day and night.
Forever leaving all worries and sorrows, in the next life they will always be upright.
Patience is a treasure of merit, always guarded by the virtuous.
Well-tamed in the mind, they are not disturbed by afflictions.
Patience is a ladder to rebirth in the heavens, escaping the fears of samsara.
If one can skillfully cultivate it, they will be liberated from the suffering of hell.
Patience is the water of merit, always filled with purity.
It can save hungry ghosts from thirst and wash away the defilements of animals.
If one exclusively cultivates the practice of forbearance, one will attain auspicious peace and happiness,
And view all sentient beings as if they were a mother of the world.
In order to nurture the true Dharma, observe the time and place,
And give rise to courageous and vigorous effort, thus seeking those various fruits.
If one is apart from the true Dharma, as well as the function of time and place,
Due to the absence of that effort, there will be much increase in lazy and indolent matters.
The wise one is very courageous, delighting in liberation and the true Dharma,
Swiftly proceeding to the heavens, similar to the speed of an arrow.
Due to the power of that effort, one skillfully manages various affairs,
In those various undertakings, all are accomplished.
Whether it is the supramundane true Dharma or the worldly benefits,
All are due to that effort; abandon this and there will be none.
If a person is far from effort, then they abandon all wholesome dharmas,
They are despised by the world, like the shadow of a rabbit obscuring the moon.
Abandoning the eightfold noble path, pure wisdom does not increase,
Only through the power of diligence can one reach a place of peace and security.
If a person is endowed with diligence, like the power and freedom of a king,
Arhats without diligence cannot accomplish enlightenment.
Understanding these merits, the faculties are not scattered and disordered,
Giving rise to a diligent mind, it is the foremost and most excellent.
Attaining pure wisdom and insight, always giving rise to right mindfulness,
Far from old age and death, one attains the realization of the true and eternal fruit.
If a person cultivates various concentrations, but is not attached to wisdom,
One should always be single-minded, giving rise to pure aspirations.
Dwelling well in a single-pointed mind, without the fault of contradiction,
Liberated from all fears, this is said to be bliss.
If the mind abides in a single object, then it is free from all doubts and uncertainties,
Pure like true gold, this is said to be happiness.
If a person's mind is tranquil, and the faculties are not scattered and confused,
Definitely heading towards enlightenment, this is said to be happiness.
